description.narrative:
Samtidigt som tillgången till mobiltelefoni har ökat explosionsartat senaste decenniet så har nya klyftor skapats mellan de som har tillgång till internet och de som inte har det. Studier visar t ex att kvinnor har mindre tillgång till internet jämfört med män. Då offentliga tjänster, ekonomiska möjligheter och samhällen i stort digitaliseras kommer tillgångsfrågan bli allt mer central – tillgång till ett fungerande, inkluderande internet blir en förutsättning för en hållbar försörjning och utveckling. De utan tillgång, oftast kvinnor och de fattigaste, riskerar att exkluderas ytterligare.
Policypåverkan och -arbete, understödd av aktuell och precis data, kan bidra till ett mer tillgängligt, prisvärt och inkluderande internet. För att säkerställa att nyttan och vinsten fördelas jämnt måste policys ta hänsyn till behov och faktiskt användande (”usage patterns”) bland marginaliserade befolkningar, särskilt till kvinnors och flickors behov och användande. Tyvärr är sådan data för närvarande inte tillgänglig i de flesta utvecklingsländer.
Insatsen Beyond Access utför hushålls- och enskilda undersökningar och analyser för att förstå de faktorer som begränsar användande av och tillgång till ICT vilket även inkluderar omständigheter "bortom tillgång" - frågor om sociala, ekonomiska, politiska och kulturella hinder för användning och tillgång till ICT.
Use surveys which while cover the factors that are constraining access to ICT but will also look 'beyond access' and cover issues of financial, legal and cultural constraints on use.

The main foreseen outcome of this project is the delivery of demand-side indicators and analysis essential to inform evidence-based policy that is more accurate and timely, and which will create the data (time-series and cross-sectional) to enable in-depth analysis of policy outcomes and points of intervention. The data will allow regulators and policy-makers to measure the impact of ICT policies and regulation.

description.narrative: The Beyond access (now After access) survey seeks to collect, generate and analyse statistics in order to inform ICT policy. Data is gathered through household and enterprise surveys to gain a nuanced understanding – beyond connectivity. This will provide a foundation to shape pro-poor policies and reduce the digital gap across countries, income groups and gender. Sida is funding country surveys is Senegal, Uganda, Sri Lanka and Ecuador, while the overall dataset – funded by IDRC – covers about 15 countries. Nationally representative survey data has been collected and is being analysed in Uganda, Senegal, Ecuador and Sri Lanka. These contain in-dept information about gender disparities, as well as urban-rural and income groups divides. This data is accessible under a creative commons license. Outputs include a comparative analysis in Africa, including nine countries. The policy paper After Access- the state of ICT in Uganda have been published, focusing on the effects of the criticised social media tax. These papers are of high quality and contain clear policy recommendations. Data is context specific and disaggregated by several parameters, this provides a decent foundation for conducting gender analyses. Some parameters that intersect with gender such as income level, urban-rural, age and disability are captured in the surveys, which enables intersectional research. Findings were used during the Democracy Project/Point of view conference to highlight the extent of gender gaps. Recommendations from the conference will be distributed to policy makers and other stakeholders. The data has been presented in national, regional and international fora, such as the IGF in Paris and the Mobile World Congress in Barcelona. As these are preliminary results, it is expected that the data will be disseminated at more policy forums going forward. A number of researchers have published papers using data from the After Access surveys. It will probably take a while to get a proper estimate of the number of papers building on the survey data, as it takes time for papers to be published. The program has an elaborated theory of change, where the role of their program in addressing the development problem and achieving impact is clear. However, the program must have a clear idea on how to practically move forward from outputs in terms of policy briefs and conference material to achieving policy impact. The expectation is that the data will feed into decisions by other stakeholders and inform policy decisions and formation. Program impact on policy formation will be assessed in the evaluation.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
